Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Kenneth J. Shea of the University of California, Irvine will develop new green chemistries for the production of hydrocarbon macromolecules from single carbon atom, renewable feedstocks (C1). The approach is to separate and study the mechanisms of the individual steps in the polymerization (initiation, propagation (early, middle and late stage), termination); to prepare reaction intermediates and measure their stabilities; and to prepare compounds necessary to enable and study the formation of stable polyethylene latexes. The broader impacts involve training undergraduate and graduate students in fundamental polymer chemistry, broadly disseminating research results via publications and presentations at conferences, participating in outreach activities through the UC Irvine Environment Institute, and the potential societal impacts of manufacturing hydrocarbon compounds and materials from renewable resources. Students will also work with industrial partners to explore large-scale applications of this chemistry for producing useful materials.

Plastics are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. At present, plastics are derived predominantly from petroleum based resources. This research will provide fundamental chemical knowledge that could be used to develop efficient, economical and practical methods for the production of plastics and waxes from abundant and sustainable carbon sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Simple hydrocarbon polymers including polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP) comprise some of the most important and widely used synthetic materials in contemporary society. These polymers, synthesized from ethylene and propylene, are derived from petroleum then processed into a myriad of products. Limited petroleum resources and the need to develop functional materials from more abundant and/or renewable carbon sources provide strong motivation for developing alternative chemistries to produce these materials or alternatives with comparable physical properties. We have developed an alternative chemistry to synthesize these useful materials. The carbon source for this chemistry does not use petroleum but rather C1 carbon feedstock that are derived from more abundant sources including coal, natural gas or nonfood biomass. Furthermore the chemistry allows a degree of control of molecular weight and topology that cannot be achieved by conventional olefin polymerization. These compositions provide opportunities to explore new applications for these materials.  In an important advance we reported a new process for synthesizing polymethylene waxes, a surrogate of PE waxes. Waxes serve as additives in lubricants, floor polishes, inks, paints, cosmetics and a wide variety of coating products. The reaction utilizes C1 carbon sources, does not require expensive transition metal catalysts, and takes place in aqueous base at or near r.t. and atmospheric pressure. This new chemistry provides a convenient and “green” route to this important and useful class of materials, which can be derived from nonpetroleum sources. (Graphic 1).

The C1 polymerization (polyhomologation) is a living polymerization that affords precise control over molecular weight and provides an extremely narrow distribution of molecular weights (PDI). Although the reaction is catalyzed by simple, inexpensive organoboranes, their oxygen sensitivity can sometimes result in some loss of PDI.  We have developed new air stable organoborane initiators that simplify the polymerization reaction and provide a safe, low-tech method for the controlled synthesis of linear hydrocarbon polymers in molecular weights that range from oligomers to > 106.

Copolymerization of two monomers can provide materials with an almost unlimited range of physical properties compared to the corresponding homopolymers.  There are a number of important types of copolymerizations including random, block, graft and gradient. The ability to control the type of copolymerization provides access to those materials but control requires a living polymerization. There are relitivly few controlled polymerization of simple hydrocarbon monomers (i.e. ethylene and propylene) and no examples of gradient PE\PP copolymers.  Gradient copolymers are materials where the instantaneous composition varies continuously from one end of the polymer chain to the other. Theoretical calculations indicate that gradient copolymers can undergo microphase separation with a blurred interface region between chemically different components.  These gradient copolymers are expected to have unique thermal properties, particularly a broad glass transition temperature (Tg ) range. We reported the first synthesis of a gradient methylidene-ethylidene copolymer via a living C1 polymerization. The copolymer has the same chemical structure as a gradient ethylene-propylene copolymer, the only difference is that the individual components (monomers) are introduced as C1 rather than C2 fragments as in PE\PP. This methodology can be used for the synthesis of multi segment hydrocarbon copolymers with control of monomer content and allows for the insertion of functionality at any location on the linear polyethylene chain.

 


Last Modified: 01/12/2016
Modified by: Kenneth J She...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Simple hydrocarbon polymers including polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP) comprise some of the most important and widely used synthetic materials in contemporary society. These polymers, synthesized from ethylene and propylene, are derived from petroleum then processed into a myriad of products. Limited petroleum resources and the need to develop functional materials from more abundant and/or renewable carbon sources provide strong motivation for developing alternative chemistries to produce these materials or alternatives with comparable physical properties. We have developed an alternative chemistry to synthesize these useful materials. The carbon source for this chemistry does not use petroleum but rather C1 carbon feedstock that are derived from more abundant sources including coal, natural gas or nonfood biomass. Furthermore the chemistry allows a degree of control of molecular weight and topology that cannot be achieved by conventional olefin polymerization. These compositions provide opportunities to explore new applications for these materials. In an important advance we reported a new process for synthesizing polymethylene waxes, a surrogate of PE waxes. Waxes serve as additives in lubricants, floor polishes, inks, paints, cosmetics and a wide variety of coating products. This new chemistry provides a convenient and "green" route to this important and useful class of materials, which can be derived from nonpetroleum sources. (Graphic 1).
